item.title: Ticket #889 (Post Permalink do not work) updated
item.dc:creator: DarkCryst
item.description:
Yes, I should have been clearer - it was in the old nightlies that it worked, not 1.2.

I'd be happy for you to get those rules working, because they don't seem to for me. Its not rocket science, but its not working as read. At least the problem is confirmed as a "won't fix" type bug - I understand the problem with i18n support and can see why that would take priority. I would say that a note in the permalinks screen would make sense - else you'll get this pointed out over.. and over.. and over again.

I'd be glad for the help as it is driving me nuts - Darkcryst@…

item.title: Ticket #889 (Post Permalink do not work) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: %category% did not exist in 1.2.2 so this is not a regression. It may have worked for you for awhile in the nightlies with the old %category% regular expression, but that regular expression broke i18n support and other things. You can either change the regular expression to suit your needs or use the alternative rules I mentioned, which do work. I can help you get those rules working if you like. mod_rewrite in older versions of apache has serious problems that are painful to work around in a generic manner. %category% just won't work out of the box with older mod_rewrite and its greedy matching problems. Such is life.

item.title: Ticket #899 (Wishlist item: hooks for file uploads) updated
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #899 (Wishlist item: hooks for file uploads) created
item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description:
This hook would be called with the uploaded file, a flag that tells about wether a thumbnail was created and the caption that was given for the upload. The ratio: plugins could hook into this one to get notified when images are uploaded and could feed that data into their databases. Otherwise they can only scan the wp-content directory but the caption is lost if the user isn't using cut-and-paste to transfer it. Would be quite handy for a plugin I am currently working on.

XMLRPC uploads via metaWeblogAPI can call the same hook but just provide an empty string for the caption (as there is no caption provided by the API call).

item.title: Ticket #889 (Post Permalink do not work) updated
item.dc:creator: DarkCryst
item.description:
as far as I'm concerned its a bug - the links do not function on a CLEAN install.

I have tried deleting the .htaccess does nothing. Changing the rules, does nothing.

This is something that *was* working in a previous, and is now broken. Hense.. its a bug. I am using a standard sever, and have done nothing wierd. Yet its not working. I searched the forums FIRST and tried everything that was mentioned there. No luck. Ryan's access rules were there, but seemingly that was a different issue.

In short I'm reporting a bug in a bugtracker. Also if the default WP 1.5 install needs apache 2 for its basic functionality to work.. thats ALSO a bug as far as I'm concerned. Especially when it worked before.

item.title: Ticket #898 (Problems with RSS feeds, error viewing) updated
item.dc:creator: kridiot
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #898 (Problems with RSS feeds, error viewing) created
item.dc:creator: kridiot
item.description: I have two installs of Wordpress 1.5, one is an updated version and the other is a clean install. www.greenkri.com is the update version, denatured.greenkri.com is the fresh install. The RSS feeds don't seem to work for either of the installs. I'm using Firefox 1.0, with the Feedview extension. Whenever I open the RSS address (​http://greenkri.com/blog/wp-rss2.php and ​http://denatured.greenkri.com/wp-rss2.php) they work fine. The problem lies in reading it in my aggregator (I am using Sage, another Firefox extension). Whenever I try to open the feed in Sage, it says "Error: File Not Found"

item.dc:creator: gbhugo
item.description: When the stripping was in, I had the following effect: when going to the comment form, the normal URL was shown. After posting the comment, the URL was changed - and in the comment form it was presented without leading ​http:// - so at least this will irritate users, even if the ​http:// is added on the next comment. I think the URL should be left untouched in the process so that the cookie contains the full URL.

item.title: Ticket #892 (Under Apache 2 pages are broken when using permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: lyklev
item.description:
Have you enabled .htaccess overrides? These are disabled by default.

Add this to your httpd.conf:

` <Directory /path/to/wordpress>

AllowOverride Options FileInfo

</Directory> `

and restart apache.

item.title: Ticket #892 (Under Apache 2 pages are broken when using permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: jatonline
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #892 (Under Apache 2 pages are broken when using permalinks) created
item.dc:creator: jatonline
item.description:
When WordPress is clean installed on a clean installation of Apache/2.0.52, PHP/4.3.10 and MySQL/4.1.10 on Windows XP SP2, adding any kind of Permalink structure in the admin interface breaks the 'pages' feature.

Posts work fine, however when ​http://site/pagename is accessed, a 404 error is received.

If permalinks are in the form: /%category%/%postname%/

then the WP 404 page is displayed, however if permalinks are set as something like: /archives/%year....%/%post_id%/

then an Apache 404 page is displayed.

item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #890 (support relative paths for enclosures) created
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Currently, enclosures only work automatically if the URL in a post is an absolute URL. Please make them work for relative URLs as well. For example, adding a link such as <a href="/audio/mymusic.mp3"> should create an enclosure to ​http://www.myblog.com/audio/mymusic.mp3 and a link such as <a href="audio/mymusic.mp3"> should create an enclosure to ​http://www.mysite.com/blogpath/audio/mymusic.mp3">

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description:
Oh, and apparently MarsEdit updates posts by doing this:

  1. Update post (setting status to draft)
  2. Update categories for post.
  3. Set post status to "published"

It does this to prevent posts from acting weirdly as they're being updated, but something is triggering an error message as part of the first step (even though the post is successfully edited in WordPress), and so MarsEdit gives up on the later steps, and the post never gets switched back to "Published"

item.title: Ticket #829 (Editing a post via XML-RPC fails, putting the post into Draft mode) updated
item.dc:creator: anonymousbugger
item.description: Just verified this is still present in 1.5 (final).

item.title: Ticket #887 (Smilies with apostrophes are Smarty-ified before being parsed (like :'( )) updated
item.dc:creator: sethkinast
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #887 (Smilies with apostrophes are Smarty-ified before being parsed (like :'( )) created
item.dc:creator: sethkinast
item.description:
As seen here: ​http://sethkinast.com/blog/archive/2005/02/14/happy-singles-awareness-day/#comment-2177

The function that turns straight apostrophes into forward and back apostrophes fires before the smiley parser. Smilies should be parsed first so things like the crying face :'( work.

item.title: Ticket #886 (admin css missing when changing wp directory) updated
item.dc:creator: trevorturk
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #886 (admin css missing when changing wp directory) created
item.dc:creator: trevorturk
item.description:
if you change your wp installation directory, the admin css goes missing. here are the instructions:

​http://wordpress.org/docs/installation/different-address/

You can solve the problem by changing:

<?php echo get_settings('siteurl') ?>

to

<?php bloginfo('wpurl') ?>

in admin-header.php on line 9.

perhaps the documentation could be updated, and/or the reference to the css file could be changed by the developers?

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) updated
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1
item.description:
Actually, a possible idea as to implimentation:

1) On the side of the password area, add a checkbox labeled "Encrypt Password". Make it a link to documentation explaining: -That by checking this box, you have no way of obtaining your password again, less resetting it -This also allows you to enter passwords much greater than 20 in length When this box is checked, and you're editing the post, the password box should display "[Encrypted]". When the form is submitted, if that field has changed at all from that string, simply update the password. 2) Just the same, make it at least 50 for plaintext. I tend to use phrases instead of passwords, that go along with the post title.

I made the change locally in my database (to raise the limit to 50), it really is a "why not" thing. The encryption option is only an added bonus that's easily implimented alongside it.

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) closed
item.dc:creator: coffee2code

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) updated
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #881 (Lengthen password field for protected posts) created
item.dc:creator: ScytheBlade1
item.description:
You know, if you lengthen the database column size to 32 and then just md5() it, users essentially would have unlimited password length for a post. However, since I take it that the ability to actually see the password that you input is enjoyed in wordpress, increasing the max length to 50 or so would be greatly appreciated.

It's just that 20 is so short...

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) updated
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description: duplicate. please delete/ignore.

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) updated
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #880 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) created
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description:
Some feed generators (in this case GeekLog) place the CDATA tag in the title. import-rss.php does not remove it.

changed line 58 to: $title = str_replace( array('<![CDATA,?]>'), , addslashes( trim($title[1]) ) );

item.title: Ticket #879 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) updated
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #879 (rss2 import leaves CDATA in $title) created
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description:
Some feed generators (in this case GeekLog) place the CDATA tag in the title. import-rss.php does not remove it.

changed line 58 to: $title = str_replace( array('<![CDATA,?]>'), , addslashes( trim($title[1]) ) );

item.title: Ticket #878 (rss2 import switches values for post_date and post_date_gmt) updated
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description: Patch changed

item.title: Ticket #878 (rss2 import switches values for post_date and post_date_gmt) created
item.dc:creator: pgarrett
item.description:
When importing an rss2 feed I discovered all posts dats were set to GMT time and the offset seemed to be ignored. Found that the values were simply being switched. Made the following changed to lined 148-149 in import-rss.php

148: switch variables DATE_ADD('$post_date', INTERVAL '$add_hours:$add_minutes' HOUR_MINUTE) and '$post_date'

149: replace $post_date with DATE_ADD('$post_date', INTERVAL '$add_hours:$add_minutes' HOUR_MINUTE)

item.title: Ticket #867 (single_month_title() broken for single-digit months) closed

item.title: Ticket #867 (single_month_title() broken for single-digit months) updated
item.dc:creator: dimock
item.description:
Status, Resolution changed

Change was applied to wrong line. Correct version (see lines with '*'):

function single_month_title($prefix = , $display = true ) {

global $m, $monthnum, $month, $year; if(!empty($monthnum) && !empty($year)) {

$my_year = $year;

* $my_month = $month[str_pad($monthnum, 2, '0', STR_PAD_LEFT)];

} elseif(!empty($m)) {

$my_year = substr($m, 0, 4);

* $my_month = $month[substr($m, 4, 2)];

}

if (!empty($my_month) && $display) {

echo $prefix . $my_month . $prefix . $my_year;

} else {

return $monthnum;

}

}
